pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:0.4: 12. The training rule on being difficult to correct
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Kosambī in Ghosita’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.2: At that time Venerable Channa was misbehaving.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.9: The Buddha is mine; the Teaching is mine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.10: The Master realized the Truth because of me.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.11: Just as a great wind lifts up grass, sticks, and fallen leaves all at once, just as a mountain stream lifts up the leaves of various water plants all at once,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.12: so too you–having various names, various families, various castes, various clans–having gone forth, have been lifted up together.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.13: So, who are you to correct me?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.15: The Buddha is mine; the Teaching is mine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.16: The Master realized the Truth because of me.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.17: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.18: “How can Venerable Channa make himself incorrigible when he’s legitimately corrected by the monks?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.19: They rebuked Venerable Channa in many ways and then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Channa:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.20: “Is it true, Channa, that you make yourself incorrigible when you’re legitimately corrected by the monks?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.23: “… Foolish man, how can you act like this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.24: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.25: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.26.1: ‘If a monk is difficult to correct, and he makes himself incorrigible when he is legitimately corrected by the monks concerning the training rules that are recited, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.27: “Venerables, don’t say anything to me, either good or bad, and I won’t say anything to you, either good or bad;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.29: then the monks should correct him like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.30: “Venerable, be easy to correct, not incorrigible.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.31: And please give legitimate correction to the monks, and the monks will do the same to you.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.32: For it’s in this way that the Buddha’s community has grown, that is, through mutual correction and mutual clearing of offenses.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.33: If that monk continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him stop.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.34: If he then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:1.35: If he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.1: If a monk is difficult to correct:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.2: if he is difficult to correct, endowed with qualities that make him hard to correct, resistant, not receiving instructions respectfully.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.3: Concerning the training rules that are recited:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.4: concerning the training rules of the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.8: about whatever training rule has been laid down by the Buddha—this is called “legitimately”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.9: When he is corrected concerning that, he makes himself incorrigible, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.10: “Venerables, don’t say anything to me, either good or bad, and I won’t say anything to you, either good or bad; please refrain from correcting me.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.12: the monk who is difficult to correct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.14: Other monks, those who see it or hear about it. They should correct him like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.15: “Venerable, be easy to correct, not incorrigible.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.17: And please give legitimate correction to the monks, and the monks will do the same to you.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.18: For it’s in this way that the Buddha’s community has grown, that is, through mutual correction and mutual clearing of offenses.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.19: And they should correct him a second
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.21: If he stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.22: If he does not stop, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.23: If those who hear about it do not say anything, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.24: That monk, even if he has to be pulled into the Sangha, should be corrected like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.25: “Venerable, be easy to correct, not incorrigible. And please give legitimate correction to the monks, and the monks will do the same to you. For it’s in this way that the Buddha’s community has grown, that is, through mutual correction
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.27: They should correct him a second
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.29: If he stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.30: If he does not stop, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.32: “And, monks, he should be pressed like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.33: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.34: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.35: The monk so-and-so makes himself incorrigible when he is legitimately corrected by the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.37: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should press him to make him stop.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.39: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.40: The monk so-and-so makes himself incorrigible when he is legitimately corrected by the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.42: The Sangha presses him to make him stop.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.43: Any monk who approves of pressing him to make him stop should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.44: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.46: For the third time I speak on this matter:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.47: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.48: The monk so-and-so makes himself incorrigible when he is legitimately corrected by the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.50: The Sangha presses him to make him stop.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.51: Any monk who approves of pressing him to make him stop should remain silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.52: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.53: The Sangha has pressed monk so-and-so to stop.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.54: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.56: After the motion, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.57: After each of the first two announcements, he commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.58: When the last announcement is finished, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.59: For one who commits the offense entailing suspension, the offense of wrong conduct and the serious offenses are annulled.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.60: He commits an offense entailing suspension:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:2.61: … Therefore, too, it is called “an offense entailing suspension”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.1.1: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, but he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.1.2: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, and he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.1.3: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as illegitimate, and he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.1.4: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as legitimate, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.1.5: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.1.6: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.2.2: if he has not been pressed;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.2.5: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss12:3.2.6: The twelfth rule, training rule on being difficult to correct, is finished.
